content.text: We set out to understand how much attention automated visualization (AutoVis) has received in the Vis literature, how its topics have shifted over time, who the key actors are, and whether AutoVis work is influential and reproducible. High-level takeaways are that AutoVis papers form a small but visible niche (roughly 2% of the corpus), with clear bursts of activity around 2015 and a pronounced peak in 2021; topical emphasis has shifted toward recommendation, mixed-initiative, and ML-driven methods while some traditional visualization-method topics have waned; and a modest set of researchers and groups produce a disproportionate share of the work. This report answers concrete questions about volume and timing (when did AutoVis grow or spike), topical evolution (which subtopics emerged or declined), influence (which papers/authors/institutions stand out), community structure (collaboration patterns and venue distribution), and methodological robustness (how reliably can we identify AutoVis papers and how often are reproducibility practices reported).

content.text: The detection-robustness chart inspects which fields triggered the regex and how many metadata fields are empty, revealing strengths and limitations of the keyword rule. Depending on the exact rule variant, between 61 and 83 papers are flagged as AutoVis (1.6–2.1% of the corpus); most matches come from Abstracts (42 matches) and AuthorKeywords (30 matches), with Titles contributing fewer. The temporal analysis highlights when AutoVis interest consolidated and whether that consolidation corresponds to higher impact or broader community uptake.

A combined count-and-proportion timeline shows AutoVis annual counts and the share of all Vis papers they represent. The clearest signal is a sharp rise centered on 2021 (16 AutoVis papers, 14.7% of that year), followed by elevated activity in 2023 (12 papers, 9.0%) and moderate levels in 2020 and 2024. Before 2014 AutoVis occurrences were very rare; after 2014 the annual fraction slowly increases with notable punctuations. Overall the long-term linear slope of the AutoVis fraction is small (≈0.002 proportion-points per year), indicating that despite recent spikes AutoVis remains a small fraction of the whole corpus and that recent years drove most of the apparent growth.
